availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Eleazer A. Paine (Monmouth, Warren County, Illinois, lawyer and soldier)

body.p: Monmouth, Warren County, Illinois, lawyer and soldier. Parkman, Geauga County, Ohio native. Son of Hendrick E. Paine and Harriet Ellsworth. Married to Charlotte Chapin on May 24, 1843. Father of Phelps Paine, Harriet Paine, Maria C. Paine, and Lydia Paine. Graduated from the U.S. Military Academy in 1839. Served on General Zachary Taylor’s staff during the Second Seminole War as a second lieutenant from 1839 to 1840. Resigned his commission in the U.S. Army on October 11, 1840. Deputy U.S. Marshall for Ohio from 1842 to 1845. Served in the Ohio militia as lieutenant colonel and brigadier general from 1842 to 1848. Practiced law in Painesville, Ohio, from 1843 to 1848. Practiced law in Monmouth, from 1848 to 1861. Lawyer in Warren County in 1850. Member of the Illinois legislature, from 1852 to 1853. Lawyer in Monmouth in 1860. Served in the 9th Illinois Volunteer Regiment (U.S.A.) as colonel from July 3, 1861 to September 3, 1861. Served as a brigadier general of U.S. Volunteers from September 3, 1861 to April 5, 1865. Resigned commission on April 5, 1865.

ab.bibl:
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Illinois, Warren County, 86A.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Illinois, Warren County, Monmouth, p. 357.
Rossiter Johnson and John Howard Brown, The Twentieth Century Biographical Dictionary of Notable Americans Volume 8 (Boston: The Biographical Society, 1904), p. 171.
James Grant Wilson and John Fiske, Appletons’ Cyclopaedia of American Biography Volume 4 (New York: D. Appleton and Company, 1898), p. 627-628.
“Investigation of General Paine’s Administration at Paducah,” Louisville Weekly Journal, October 4, 1864.
